awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Vacuum Arc Control using Arc Position Sensing and Induced Magnetic Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will provide commercial validation at scale of feedback-based control of arc behavior within the vacuum arc remelting (VAR) process.  This will improve VAR performance in the production of specialty metals, resulting in improvements to ingot quality while reducing electricity consumption.  Specialty metals, such as titanium and nickel alloys, are used in critical high-performance parts in industries such as aerospace, energy, and medicine, where the failure of these parts may lead to catastrophic systems failures and potentially life-threatening situations. In a VAR furnace, extreme temperature gradients from constricted and/or diffuse arcs sustained between the melting electrode and ingot can cause non-homogeneous material and inclusion defects, resulting in up to 8% yield loss per ingot, representing $1.024 billion in losses across the domestic industry.  Improved control over the arc distributions during the melting of these metals is expected to decrease the frequency of defects in the final product and increase overall yield from the process. The proposed project is expected to reduce these loses by up to 50% through the application of active, feedback control of the arc dynamics. This type of control is expected to increase yield, decrease energy requirements, and increase safety of the manufacturing process industry-wide.

This project will result in a system capable of detecting and manipulating the distribution of the arcs utilized during VAR processing. The Phase I effort showed that it is possible to simultaneously detect arc locations on the electrode and influence their movements, using electromagnetic coils, in real time. In Phase II, the arc measurements will be coupled through feedback to control the arc distribution in an industrial-scale research VAR, providing proof of concept at industrial scale. In so doing, the optimal electromagnetic coil geometry, hardware, and materials for driving the arc motion at scale will be identified and constructed. A series of industrial experiments are planned to validate the control system. The chemical composition of the ingots produced during controlled and uncontrolled conditions will be characterized to correlate defects with observed arc behaviors and to identify optimal control parameters.  Similarly, the measured arc distributions will be used to validate the computational solidification modeling, which will be used to identify probable defect regions. The combination of experimental data and validated simulation results will be used to inform the VAR feedback control system regarding optimal arc distribution, yielding an improved control strategy for tailoring the melt process and improving ingot quality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The overall scope of this SBIR Phase I and Phase II effort was to scale and commercialize a novel, passive measurement device for monitoring plasma dynamics during Vacuum Arc Remelting and utilizing this measurement as a control variable in a new feedback control system. The goal is to increase the quality of metals being manufactured for such critical and extreme environments as jet engines so that catastrophic failures don?t occur as they did in American Airlines Flight 383 in October of 2016 (Figure 1).

Beginning with a concept in 2005, and based originally on funding provided by the Specialty Metals Processing Consortium, the ?Electric Current Locator? was developed and patented by the Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. In 2014, co-Inventor Dr. Paul King formed Ampere Scientific in an effort to scale, harden and commercialize the technology. Obtaining an exclusive license of the core patent in 2015, Ampere Scientific began its multi-year scaling effort culminating in product sales starting in 2019. During this period, our NSF SBIR Phase I (Awarded Dec 2016) and Phase II (Awarded Sept 2018) provided developmental funding to place prototype measurement systems in the field (Figure 2 and 3) for industrial validation, without which, the technology may not ever be adopted. These industrial prototype systems provided both a platform for industrial hardening the technology against the use environment, as well as providing the necessary data for validation of the measurement approach leading to adoption of the systems.

During the course of validation, Ampere Scientific built a research scale Vacuum Arc Remelting furnace. This VAR was utilized to develop a laboratory understanding of arc dynamics through a multitude of data types (eg magnetic flux, optical, electrical, and thermal) to better understand the complex plasma arc driven system. The culmination of these efforts led to the ability to precisely measure current conduction pathways within a finite volume where no known sensor can survive. This enabled the use of, and validation of the use of transverse magnetic fields (Figure 4) as a means of manipulating the current pathways in order to manufacture higher quality metals (Figure 5).

Overall, the program was such a success, that Ampere Scientific has grown from just the 2 founders to a thriving company of 14 employees and growing. In so doing, Ampere Scientific has received funding from Angel Investors, has entered 3 Joint Development Agreements for its core product, has sold 7 units and won the Best Paper Award at the only specialty metals processing conference in the world (held every other year). We continue to push ourselves to learn from the vast quantities of data taken and to push the boundaries of our understanding of the plasma process.

Finally, Ampere Scientific is happy to announce that recent advances and investments into Ampere Scientific have seen its manufacturing arm grow beyond the simple machining that currently exists, but we also are expecting to receive ISO 9001 certification in early 2023. Overall, we are showing that these advancements in metals processing will lead to cleaner materials, yielding safer travel!

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Paul E King

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1 - AA383 burns after rotator disk failure caused an uncontained engine failure on takeoff. The incident resulted in the complete loss of the airplane but fortunately the pilots were able to save everyone on the flight.
    CNN News3
    Public Domain
    Paul E King
    AA383 at Chicago OHare airport
  • Figure 2 - Magnetic field sensor assembly installed at an industrial facility as part of or validation process.
    Ampere Scientific
    Copyrighted
    Paul E King
    Figure 2 - Magnetic field sensor assembly
  • Figure 3 - Render of the Ampere Scientific control system utilizing transverse magnetic fields to manipulate the current conduction pathway within a vacuum arc remelting furnace.
    Ampere Scientific
    Copyrighted
    Paul E King
    Figure 3 - Control system
  • Figure 4 - Ampere Scientific HMI during operations showing application of transverse magnetic fields in order to tailor the heat flux during VAR processing.
    Ampere Scientific
    Copyrighted
    Paul E King
    Figure 4 - Control System intereface
  • Figure 5 - Metallurgical results comparing an uncontrolled solidification in an ingot to a controlled solidification in an ingot. Here we demonstrate how controlling the heat flux can be utilized to control the solidification structure of an ingot.
    Ampere Scientific
    Copyrighted
    Paul E King
    Figure 5 - Metallurgical Results
